questions.question_text:
SIMULATION
-

Please wait while the virtual machine loads. Once loaded, you may proceed to the lab section. This may take a few minutes, and the wait time will not be deducted from your overall test time.

When the Next button is available, click it to access the lab section. In this section, you will perform a set of tasks in a live environment. While most functionality will be available to you as it would be in a live environment, some functionality (e.g. copy and paste, ability to navigate to external websites) will not be possible by design.

Scoring is based on the outcome of performing the tasks stated in the lab. In other words, it doesn’t matter how you accomplish the task, if you successfully perform it, you will earn credit for that task.

Labs are not timed separately, and this exam may have more than one lab that you must complete. You can use as much time as you would like to complete each lab. But you should manage your time appropriately to ensure that you are able to complete the lab(s) and all other sections of the exam in the time provided.

Please not that once you submit your work by clicking the Next button within a lab, you will NOT be able to return to the lab.

You may now click next to proceed to the lab.

Username and password.

Use the following login credentials as needed:

To enter your username, place your cursor in the Sign in box and click on the username below.

To enter your password, place your cursor in the Enter password box and click on the password below.

Microsoft 365 Username:
admin@XXXXXXXXXXX.onmicrosoft.com
Microsoft 365 Password: XXXXXXXXXXXX

If the Microsoft 365 portal does not load successfully in the browser, press CTRL-K to reload the portal in a new browser tab.

The following information is for technical support purposes only:

Lab Instance: 26178313
-


Task 12
-

You need to create a Microsoft 365 group named TeamsAdmin that can manage Teams Phone configurations without being able to manage teams and channels.

To complete this task, sign in to the Microsoft 365 portal.

discussion.content: I think the role should be Team Communication Administrator or Teams Telephony Administrator (least privilege)
365 group cannot be assigned to an administrative role, you havo to create a security group and then assign teams device administrator

I'm only able to do this in "Microsoft Entra admin center"
You create the O365 group and make sure you choose YES under "Microsoft Entra roles can be assigned to the group"
Then you're able to click on the group settings and click "Assigned Roles" and assign Teams Device Administrator. Holy smokes, anyone know where we can get some updated exams??
Can find Teams device admin role only in AAD console but 365 console. Do not know what I am doing wrong.

I don't fully understand the answers , can anyone simplify it ?
Thanks

comments.content: i agree with you but hard to say without the simulation present.

discussion.content: "You need to create a M365 group" is mentioned in the task. Nothing with security group.. Guys read the task.
create Security Group in Microsoft 365 Portal and assign the Teams Device Administrator Role
create Security Group in Azure AD and assign the Teams Device Administrator Role
possible in Azure AD. Create the Group in Azure AD and assign the Teams Devices admin role

TeamsConsumer is needed for Teams personal accounts:
https://erik365.blog/2021/11/12/how-to-enable-teams-business-users-to-chat-with-teams-personal-accounts/
But firstly you need to enable AllowFederatedUsers
Correct, however the order should not matter https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/skype/set-cstenantfederationconfiguration

That’s right:
-AllowFederatedUsers: When set to True (the default value) users will be potentially allowed to communicate with users from other domains. If this property is set to False then users cannot communicate with users from other domains

-AllowTeamsConsumer: Allows federation with people using Teams with an account that's not managed by an organization.

Not valid here would be:


-AllowPublicUsers: When set to True (the default value) users will be potentially allowed to communicate with users who have accounts on public IM and presence providers such as Windows Live, Yahoo, and AOL.

It’s only for specific providers (Public IM)

Set-CsTenantFederationConfiguration -AllowTeamsConsumer $true -AllowPublicUsers $true

OR
Set-CsTenantFederationConfiguration -AllowPublicUsers $true -AllowTeamsConsumer $true

Explaination :
Set-CsTenantFederationConfiguration -->enable and disable federation with other domains and federation with public providers.

-AllowPublicUsers -->When set to True (the default value) users will be potentially allowed to communicate with users who have accounts on public IM and presence providers such as Windows Live, Yahoo, and AOL.

-AllowTeamsConsumer--> Allows federation with people using Teams with an account that's not managed by an organization.

reference:https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/skype/set-cstenantfederationconfiguration?view=skype-ps
I'd go for -AllowPublicUsers and -AllowTeamsConsumers given the "personal use" requirement.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Teams.

You need to ensure that the users in your organization can communicate with external users who use Teams for personal use.

How should you complete the PowerShell cmdlets? To answer, drag the appropriate values to the correct targets. Each value may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Common Area Phone is no more exist, Now is Microsoft Teams Shared Devices.
and TSD including Phone System.

Selected Answer: C
I am pretty sure the answer should be Teams Room Standard license. (Although the correct name is Teams Room Basic.)

In the following link about Common Area Phone licenses, it states "For a more complete meeting room experience, including audio conferencing, consider purchasing a dedicated Teams Rooms license with a Teams Rooms device instead."
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/set-up-common-area-phones

"The Teams Rooms Basic license includes scheduling, joining meetings, content sharing, and collaborative white boarding." An organization can have up to 25 Teams Room Basic licenses and this question is requesting licenses for 20 conference phones.

Selected Answer: A
Should be Teams Phone or E5 or Microsoft Teams Shared Devices (old Common Area Phone)

Microsoft Teams Rooms Basic licenses aren't supported on and won't work with Teams Phone devices. An account with a Basic license assigned will be blocked from sign in.
Teams Shared Devices,

Selected Answer: A
To deploy conference phones that support Direct Routing and one-touch join for Teams calendar meetings, you would require the Common Area Phone license for each phone.

The Common Area Phone license is specifically designed for devices like conference phones, lobby phones, and shared devices that are not associated with a specific user. It provides the necessary capabilities for these devices to connect to Microsoft Teams, including the ability to make and receive calls, access voicemail, and join Teams meetings.
Correct is c

Selected Answer: C
correct answer is C 

Key word here is Direct Routing 

Teams Room Standard license will give you the Phone System + Audio conferencing license +exchange mailbox for calendar scheduling.

E3 will not give you Phone system & Audio conferencing but only exchange mailbox

comments.content: Forgot to add Common Area phone doesn't have an exchange mailbox so its ruled out .

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E3 subscription that uses Microsoft Teams.

You plan to deploy 20 conference phones that will support Direct Routing and one-touch join for Teams calendar meetings.

Which type of license do you require for each phone?

comments.content: It would be great if you answer them according to the questions as your answers does not reflect the options.

the given answers are correct. They havent given you all the options, but what they have given seems to be the right order according to the link from nwmc
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-barriers-policies?view=o365-worldwide

discussion.content:
STEP1: Prerequisites (among others):
- Scoped directory search
- Admin consent for IB in Microsoft Teams

STEP2: Segment users in your organization

STEP 3: Create IB policies

STEP 4: Apply IB policies

STEP 5: Configuration for information barriers on SharePoint and OneDrive

…….

To effectively block communication between users in the trading department and the research department, follow these steps in sequence:

1. **Make a list of segments to define**: 
Identify the specific user groups (segments) that need to be separated. For example, create segments for the trading department and the research department.

2. **Create information barrier policies**: 
Information barrier policies allow you to restrict communication and collaboration between specific groups of users. Define policies that prevent users in the trading department from communicating with users in the research department¹[1].

3. **Provide admin consent for the Information Barrier Processor**: 
Ensure that the necessary permissions are granted for implementing information barriers. Admin consent is essential for the effective functioning of these policies¹[1].

4. **From the Microsoft Teams admin center, enable scoped directory search**: 
Scoped directory search allows you to limit the visibility of certain users to others.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-barriers-policies?view=o365-worldwide

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

Your company has a trading department and a research department.

The company purchases a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.

You plan to deploy Microsoft 365 E5 licenses to all users.

You need to block communication between the users in the trading department and the users in the research department.

Which four actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.

//IMG//

Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.com.
You need to prevent guest users in the tenant from using cameras during Microsoft Teams meetings.
Solution: From the Azure Active Directory admin center, you modify the External collaboration settings.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: The guest settings like Meeting, Chats and calls are controlled via 'Teams Admin center' -> Org-wide-> Guest access

Correct answer is B coz in questions you have this formula "From the Azure Active Directory admin center, you modify the External collaboration settings." - No, you cannot setup this AAD Admin center.

https://debug.to/1307/how-to-prevent-guest-users-from-using-camera-in-microsoft-teams
B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
The goal is not met

Correct answer is B
Teams Admin Center > Users > Guest access - Meeting (IP video On/Off)

correct answer is B
Teams AC -> Org-Wide settings -> Guest Access -> Allow IP video

Selected Answer: B
correct answer is B
Answer is correct...
TAM > Guest access > under meeting, turn the "Allow IP video" off.
'You need to prevent guest users in the tenant from using cameras during Microsoft Teams meetings.' -> this is clearly Teams AC -> Org-Wide settings -> Guest Access -> Allow IP video
It's possible in Collaboration restrictions to add taget domains

It is a very tricky question. The correct answer is:
Org-wide settings => Guest access => Meeting => Allow IP video. 
But does't match "modify the External collaboration settings"? There is not a setting with the same name. There is "External Access" setting which is different. So the answer is "YES" for "Microsoft Teams Admin Center" but "NO" for "modify the External collaboration settings"
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/manage-guests
There are no External Collaboration settings on the Teams Admin center, they can only be found on Azure AD.

questions.answer_description:
Guest access in Teams allows people outside you organization to access teams and channels. When you turn on Guest Access, you can turn on or off features guests users can or can't use.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/set-up-guests
